citeinfo.title: Landsat 9 Surface Reflectance Imagery for Wildlife Management Areas in Alabama (May–July 2024)

descript.abstract: This dataset consists of Landsat 9 Operational Land Imager (OLI-2) surface reflectance imagery acquired between May and July 2024, covering Wildlife Management Areas (WMAs) across Alabama. The imagery was used to extract spectral bands and vegetation indices in support of a supervised land cover classification model. Surface reflectance values were derived from Tier 1 Collection 2 products and represent atmospherically corrected surface-level observations.
descript.purpose: The imagery was used to support remote sensing-based land cover classification across Alabama’s Wildlife Management Areas. Landsat 9 surface reflectance data offers consistent, multispectral information for monitoring vegetation, habitat conditions, and land use across large areas.

attracc.attraccr: Surface reflectance values were derived using USGS’s atmospheric correction algorithms for Tier 1 Collection 2 data. Vegetation indices were computed using standard equations, and results were verified visually to ensure accuracy and absence of processing artifacts. Only high-quality, cloud-free imagery was used in analyses.

dataqual.logic: All bands and derived indices were stacked and co-registered in ArcGIS Pro. The raster dataset was checked for consistent spatial resolution and projection (NAD 1983 UTM Zone 16N). Derived indices were validated to ensure correct scaling and alignment across scenes.
dataqual.complete: The dataset includes complete Landsat 9 surface reflectance coverage for all targeted WMAs in Alabama during the 202405–202407 period. Cloudy scenes or areas with missing data were excluded to ensure classification quality. All relevant spectral bands and indices were included.

procstep.procdesc: Landsat 9 Collection 2 Surface Reflectance Tier 1 imagery was accessed through Google Earth Engine (GEE), filtered for <10% cloud cover, and exported as GeoTIFF files for the study area covering Wildlife Management Areas in Alabama. The imagery, acquired between 202405 and 202407, was composited in GEE using the median of available cloud-free pixels. After export, all raster bands were imported into R, where spectral indices including NDVI, SAVI, and EVI were calculated using raster-based band math. Processed layers were stacked, rescaled to a 0–1 range, and reprojected to NAD 1983 UTM Zone 16N for use in supervised land cover classification.
